QuestionStatement: An improvement in production technology for a certain good leads to
AnswerChoices: An increase in demand for the good
An increase in the supply of the good
An increase in the price of the good
A shortage of the good
A surplus of the good

QuestionStatement: A firm doubles all of its inputs and finds that is has more than doubled its output.  This situation is an example of
AnswerChoices: Increasing marginal returns
Diminishing marginal returns
Constant returns to scale
Increasing returns to scale
Decreasing returns to scale

QuestionStatement: Reducing the tariff on Canadian beer sold in the United States will most likely have which of the following effects on the market for beer produced and sold in the United States?
AnswerChoices: The quantity of United States beer purchased will increase
Total expenditure on United States beer will increase
The supply of United States beer will increase
The price of United States beer will decrease
More workers will be employed in the production of United States beer

QuestionStatement: Suppose that the license paid by each business to operate in a city increases from $400 per year to $500 per year.  What effect will this increase have on a firm’s short-run costs?  Marginal Cost   Average Total Cost   Average Variable Costa.      Increase            Increase            Increaseb.      Increase            Increase            No effectc.      No effect            No effect            No effectd.      No effect            Increase            Increasee.      No effect            Increase            No effect
AnswerChoices: See above
See above
See above
See above
See above

QuestionStatement: In a perfectly competitive market, an individual farmer intending to increase her revenue decides to increase the price of her crop by 20 percent.  As a result her total revenue will
AnswerChoices: Decrease
Stay the same
Increase by less than 20 percent
Increase by 20 percent
Increase by more than 20 percent

QuestionStatement: If the supply of a factor or production is fixed, which of the following will be true of its price?
AnswerChoices: Supply is irrelevant to the determination of factor price
A positive factor price cannot be justified on economic grounds
Factor price will be determined by the demand for the fixed amount of the factor
Factor price will not be determined by supply and demand analysis
Factor price will be zero, since no payment is necessary to secure the services of the factor

QuestionStatement: Which of the following is true if a perfectly competitive industry is earning zero economic profits in the long run?
AnswerChoices: The level of investment in long-run equilibrium is greater than the efficient level
Relatively few firms are able to survive the competitive pressures in the long run
Some firms will be forced to transfer their resources to more lucrative uses
The resources invested in this industry are earning at least as high a return as they would in any alternative use
Firms will exit until economic profits become positive

QuestionStatement: The figure above shows cost and revenue curves for a public regulated power company and three possible prices for its output.  Which of the following statements about those prices is most accurate?
AnswerChoices: If P
were approved, regulation would not be needed and the company would have every incentive to lower rates to P
P
is inefficient; it is better to have several utilities serve the area than to approve P
P
is idea; it gives stockholders the maximum rate of return and protects consumers from exploitation.
P
would maximize consumer welfare; greater electric use at this low rate would guarantee stockholders a fair rate of return.
P
would maximize consumer welfare, but a public subsidy would be needed to keep the company in business

QuestionStatement: In a market economy, public goods such as community police protection are unlikely to be provided in sufficient quantity by the private sector because
AnswerChoices: Private firms are less efficient at producing public goods than is the government
The use of public goods cannot be withheld from those who do not pay for them
Consumers lack information about the benefits of public goods
Consumers do not value public goods highly enough for firms to produce them profitably
Public goods are inherently too important to be left to private firms to produce
